docs.abstract: In states where laws now limit classroom discussions about race and discrimination, many teachers are watching what they say, and are more anxious about their jobs.
docs.snippet: In states where laws now limit classroom discussions about race and discrimination, many teachers are watching what they say, and are more anxious about their jobs.
docs.lead_paragraph: In rural New Hampshire, a Spanish teacher took down a “Black Lives Matter” sign in her classroom.

headline.main: Teachers Tackle Black History Month, Under New Restrictions
headline.print_headline: Teaching Black History Month, Under New Limits

byline.original: By Jacey Fortin and Giulia Heyward

docs.abstract: The first Black student to receive a doctorate from the University of Georgia, she devoted her life to advocating for diversity in science and math education.
docs.snippet: The first Black student to receive a doctorate from the University of Georgia, she devoted her life to advocating for diversity in science and math education.
docs.lead_paragraph: Shirley McBay, who in 1966 became the first Black person to receive a doctorate from the University of Georgia, and who went on to be a leading voice for diversity in science and math education, died on Nov. 27 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 86.

headline.main: Shirley McBay, Pioneering Mathematician, Is Dead at 86
headline.print_headline: Shirley McBay, 86, Mathematician Who Pushed for Diversity in STEM

docs.abstract: A debate on the racial equity policy that shapes college admissions in this country.
docs.snippet: A debate on the racial equity policy that shapes college admissions in this country.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court has agreed to hear two cases, one involving Harvard and the other the University of North Carolina, that could reshape college admissions. Both schools are being accused of race-based discrimination in their admission practices. In the coming year, the court will examine whether it’s lawful for college admissions offices to consider a student’s race.

headline.main: Affirmative Action and America’s ‘Cosmetically Diverse’ College Campuses

docs.abstract: He devised a plan to desegregate Boston’s public schools. He also stood up against sexism in the Episcopal Church.
docs.snippet: He devised a plan to desegregate Boston’s public schools. He also stood up against sexism in the Episcopal Church.
docs.lead_paragraph: Charles Vert Willie, a sociologist whose work reshaped our understanding of school integration and Black family life, and whose stand against sexism in the Episcopal Church paved the way for the ordination of women priests, died on Jan. 11 at his home in Brighton, Mass. He was 94.

headline.main: Charles Vert Willie, 94, Dies; Studied, and Defended, Racial Diversity
headline.print_headline: Charles Vert Willie, 94, Who Studied and Solved Social Problems, Dies

docs.abstract: This is a terrible time for liberal institutions to weaken academic freedom.
docs.snippet: This is a terrible time for liberal institutions to weaken academic freedom.
docs.lead_paragraph: A libertarian constitutional law scholar named Ilya Shapiro sent out some ugly tweets last week. Shapiro, who’d recently been hired by Georgetown University’s law school, criticized Joe Biden’s pledge to nominate a Black woman to the Supreme Court, arguing that the Indian-born judge Sri Srinivasan was “objectively” the “best pick.” But Srinivasan, wrote Shapiro, “alas doesn’t fit into latest intersectionality hierarchy so we’ll get lesser black woman.” He claimed that if Biden considered only Black women, whoever he chose would always have an “asterisk attached.”

headline.main: Georgetown Law, Don’t Punish Your New Hire Over His ‘Lesser Black Woman’ Tweet

docs.abstract: More than a dozen schools could be either shuttered or merged before the fall.
docs.snippet: More than a dozen schools could be either shuttered or merged before the fall.
docs.lead_paragraph: What is typically a dull affair, a weeknight meeting of a school board, was anything but on Monday night.

headline.main: Oakland District Weighs Closing Schools Amid Budget Shortage

docs.abstract: The board voted unanimously to remove the Pulitzer Prize-winning graphic novel from classrooms because it contained swear words, according to minutes from the meeting.
docs.snippet: The board voted unanimously to remove the Pulitzer Prize-winning graphic novel from classrooms because it contained swear words, according to minutes from the meeting.
docs.lead_paragraph: A school board in Tennessee voted unanimously this month to ban “Maus,” a Pulitzer Prize-winning graphic novel about the Holocaust, from being taught in its classrooms because the book contains material that board members said was inappropriate for students.

headline.main: School Board in Tennessee Bans Teaching of Holocaust Novel ‘Maus’
headline.print_headline: Tennessee Board Bans Teaching of Holocaust Novel

docs.abstract: Schools deploy creative measures to staff classrooms.
docs.snippet: Schools deploy creative measures to staff classrooms.
docs.lead_paragraph: I’m Giulia Heyward, and since this school year began, I’ve covered the nationwide labor shortage affecting so many of the country’s schools.

byline.original: By Amelia Nierenberg and Giulia Heyward

docs.abstract: A Republican legislator in Virginia who campaigned against critical race theory introduced a bill that incorrectly said the Lincoln-Douglas debates were between Abraham Lincoln and Frederick Douglass.
docs.snippet: A Republican legislator in Virginia who campaigned against critical race theory introduced a bill that incorrectly said the Lincoln-Douglas debates were between Abraham Lincoln and Frederick Douglass.
docs.lead_paragraph: Amid a flurry of bills nationwide that seek to ban the teaching of critical race theory in schools, one such proposal in Virginia stood out.

headline.main: A Bill Proposed a New Way to Teach History. It Got the History Wrong.

byline.original: By Maria Cramer and Amanda Holpuch

docs.abstract: A nondiscrimination provision in the $1.85 trillion social policy bill could disqualify some religious organizations, spurring a fight over who can benefit from President Biden’s landmark bill.
docs.snippet: A nondiscrimination provision in the $1.85 trillion social policy bill could disqualify some religious organizations, spurring a fight over who can benefit from President Biden’s landmark bill.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A coalition of conservative religious groups is waging an intensive lobbying effort to remove a nondiscrimination provision from President Biden’s ambitious prekindergarten and child care plans, fearing it would disqualify their programs from receiving a huge new infusion of federal money.

headline.main: Biden’s Child Care Plan Faces Resistance From Religious Groups
headline.print_headline: Looming Fight On Faith, Funds And Child Care
